qas.question: What was the name of the man that tried to shoot Queen Victoria?
On what date did John Francis try to shoot Queen Victoria?
Where was Queen Victoria when Francis tried to shoot her?

answers.text: riding in a carriage along The Mall, London

qas.question: What happened to Francis after his attempt to shoot Victoria?
Why did Francis fail to kill Queen Victoria?
Who made two unsuccessful attempts on Queen Victoria's life in 1842?
What was John Francis's eventual sentence for the attempt on the Queens life?
Who shot at Queen Victoria on July 3, days after John Francis's sentence was commuted?
Who fired a shot at Queen Victoria's carriage in 1849?
What person recieved a seven year transportation sentence for striking Victoria on the head with his cane?
Who escaped Victoria's guards after attempting to fire a shot at her?
What happened to John Francis after his second attempt to fire on the Queen?

answers.text: death sentence was commuted to transportation for life

qas.question: What did John William Bean try to fire at Queen Victoria?
What were the consequences of John William Bean's attempt to fire at the Queen?
When did William Hamilton fire a powder charge at Victoria's carriage?
What was the name of the man that tried to save Queen Victoria?
On what date did John Francis try to help Queen Victoria?

plausible_answers.text: riding in a carriage along The Mall, London

qas.question: Where wasn't Queen Victoria when Francis tried to shoot her?
What happened to Francis after his attempt not to shoot Victoria?
Why did Francis fail to help Queen Victoria?

context: On <a1_0><b16_0>29 May 1842<b16_0/><a1_0/>, Victoria was <a2_0><b17_0>riding in a carriage along The Mall, London<b17_0/><a2_0/>, when <a0_0><a5_0><a10_0><b15_0>John Francis<b15_0/><a10_0/><a5_0/><a0_0/> aimed a pistol at her but <a4_0><b19_0>the gun did not fire<b19_0/><a4_0/>; <a3_0><b18_0>he escaped<b18_0/><a3_0/>. The following day, Victoria drove the same route, though faster and with a greater escort, in a deliberate attempt to provoke Francis to take a second aim and catch him in the act. As expected, Francis shot at her, but he was seized by plain-clothes policemen, and convicted of high treason. On 3 July, two days after Francis's <a11_0>death sentence was commuted to <a6_0>transportation for life<a11_0/><a6_0/>, <a7_0>John William Bean<a7_0/> also tried to fire a pistol at the Queen, but it was loaded only with <a12_0>paper and tobacco<a12_0/> and had too little charge. Edward Oxford felt that the attempts were encouraged by his acquittal in 1840. Bean was sentenced to <a13_0>18 months in jail<a13_0/>. In a similar attack in <a14_0>1849<a14_0/>, unemployed Irishman <a8_0>William Hamilton<a8_0/> fired a powder-filled pistol at Victoria's carriage as it passed along Constitution Hill, London. In 1850, the Queen did sustain injury when she was assaulted by a possibly insane ex-army officer, <a9_0>Robert Pate<a9_0/>. As Victoria was riding in a carriage, Pate struck her with his cane, crushing her bonnet and bruising her forehead. Both Hamilton and Pate were sentenced to seven years' transportation.
